Mike Clark wrote:
> 
> On Jun 19, 2004, at 2:33 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> 
>  >> My questions are:
>  >> Is there a way to explicitly control the order of execution of test
>  >> methods within a test case, so to control the access to commonly
>  >> used resources and account for their state? (system ports, JDBC
>  >> connections, etc.)
>  >>
>  >> Is JUnit the tool for such a job?
>  >
>  > No, it isn't. Still, whenenver I want to do something in my design that
>  > JUnit makes difficult, it is /usually/ a sign that my design needs
>  > improvement.
> 
> I see no reason why JUnit couldn't be used in this scenario.  You can
> control order by 1) putting all 3 operations in one test method (aka
> linear programming) or 2) explicitly adding test methods to a test
> suite in the order you desire (it's an ordered collection under the
> hood).
> 
> Now, is that a design smell?  Probably.  Does that mean JUnit isn't the
> right tool?  I don't think so.  The computer-checked assertions are
> still valuable over, say, visual inspection.  And perhaps not having to
> visually inspect results every time the tests are run will afford more
> time to address the design smell.

Absolutely agreed. Withdrawn. Good to see you around, Mike.
